pages.title: About
pages.content:
About This Documentation

This knowledge base is designed to help developers and users find the information they need quickly. Our documentation covers everything from getting started guides to advanced API references.

Our Mission

We believe great documentation is the foundation of great software. Every feature, endpoint, and configuration option is documented with clear examples and explanations.

Contributing

Found an error or want to suggest an improvement? We welcome contributions from the community. Check our contribution guidelines to get started.
pages.seo_description: Learn about our documentation and knowledge base.

pages.title: Getting Started
pages.content:
Quick Start

Get up and running in just a few minutes. This guide covers the essential steps to set up your development environment.

Prerequisites

  • PHP 8.1 or higher
  • Composer package manager
  • A supported database (MySQL, PostgreSQL, or SQLite)

Installation

Install via Composer:

composer create-project jessie/cms my-project
cd my-project
php jessie serve

Configuration

Copy the example configuration file and update your database credentials:

cp config.example.php config.php

Note: Make sure your web server has write permissions to the uploads/ and cache/ directories.

Next Steps

Once installed, explore the API Reference or follow our step-by-step tutorials.
pages.seo_description: Quick start guide for setting up and configuring your project.

pages.title: API Reference
pages.content:
REST API Overview

Our API follows REST conventions and returns JSON responses. All endpoints require authentication via API key or OAuth token.

Base URL

https://api.example.com/v1/

Authentication

Include your API key in the request header:

Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY

Endpoints

MethodEndpointDescription
GET/pagesList all pages
GET/pages/:slugGet a single page
POST/pagesCreate a new page
PUT/pages/:idUpdate a page
DELETE/pages/:idDelete a page

Rate Limits

API requests are limited to 100 requests per minute per API key. Rate limit headers are included in every response.

Need higher limits? Contact our team for enterprise plans.

pages.title: FAQ
pages.content:
Frequently Asked Questions

What are the system requirements?

You need PHP 8.1+, a web server (Apache or Nginx), and a database. SQLite works great for small sites and development.

How do I update to the latest version?

Run composer update in your project directory. Always back up your database before updating.

Can I use a custom domain?

Yes! Point your domain's DNS to your server and update the configuration file with your domain name.

How do I create custom templates?

Create a new PHP file in your theme's templates/ directory. The filename (without extension) becomes the template name available in the admin panel.

Is there an API?

Yes, we provide a full REST API. See the API Reference for complete documentation.

Where can I get support?

Visit our Support page or join our community forum for help from the team and other users.

articles.title: Building Your First Page
articles.excerpt: Learn how to create, edit, and publish your first page using the admin panel and template system.
articles.content:
In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create your first page from scratch. We'll cover the admin panel basics, content editing, and template selection.

Step 1: Access the Admin Panel

Navigate to /admin and log in with your credentials. You'll see the dashboard with quick links to common tasks.

Step 2: Create a New Page

Click Pages → New Page in the sidebar. Fill in the title and slug — the slug becomes the URL path for your page.

Step 3: Add Content

Use the content editor to add text, images, and media. The editor supports rich text formatting and raw HTML.

# Markdown-style content
You can write content using the visual editor
or switch to HTML mode for full control.

Step 4: Choose a Template

Select a template from the dropdown. Different templates provide different layouts and features.

Tip: Preview your page before publishing to see how it looks with the selected template.

Step 5: Publish

Click Save & Publish to make your page live. You can always edit or unpublish it later.

articles.title: Working with the REST API
articles.excerpt: A practical guide to authenticating, making requests, and handling responses from the REST API.
articles.content:
This guide walks you through making your first API request, from authentication to handling responses.

Getting Your API Key

Generate an API key from the admin panel under Settings → API Keys. Keep your key secure and never expose it in client-side code.

Making Your First Request

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_KEY" \
  https://api.example.com/v1/pages

Response Format

All responses are JSON. Successful requests return a data field:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    { "id": 1, "title": "Home", "slug": "home" },
    { "id": 2, "title": "About", "slug": "about" }
  ]
}

Error Handling

Error responses include a message field with a human-readable description:

{
  "status": "error",
  "message": "Invalid API key",
  "code": 401
}

Always check the HTTP status code first, then parse the response body for details.

articles.title: Customizing Themes
articles.excerpt: Learn how to modify existing themes or create your own from scratch with custom templates and styles.
articles.content:
Themes control the entire look and feel of your site. This guide covers theme structure, customization, and creation.

Theme Structure

Every theme follows the same directory structure:

themes/your-theme/
├── theme.json          # Theme metadata
├── layout.php          # Main layout wrapper
├── assets/
│   ├── css/style.css   # Theme styles
│   └── js/main.js      # Theme scripts
├── templates/
│   ├── home.php        # Home page template
│   ├── page.php        # Default page template
│   ├── article.php     # Single article
│   └── articles.php    # Article listing
└── demo.json           # Demo content

Customizing Colors

Edit theme.json to change the color palette. CSS variables are automatically generated from these values.

Creating Templates

Add new PHP files to the templates/ directory. Each template receives $page, $content, and other variables from the CMS.

Templates are automatically discovered — no registration required.

articles.title: Deployment Guide
articles.excerpt: Step-by-step instructions for deploying to production, including server configuration and optimization.
articles.content:
Ready to go live? This guide covers everything you need for a production deployment.

Server Requirements

  • PHP 8.1+ with common extensions (mbstring, pdo, json)
  • Web server: Apache with mod_rewrite or Nginx
  • SSL certificate (Let's Encrypt recommended)
  • At least 512MB RAM

Apache Configuration

<VirtualHost *:443>
  ServerName docs.example.com
  DocumentRoot /var/www/cms/public
  
  <Directory /var/www/cms/public>
    AllowOverride All
    Require all granted
  </Directory>
</VirtualHost>

Performance Tips

  • Enable OPcache for PHP
  • Configure browser caching for static assets
  • Use a CDN for media files
  • Enable gzip compression

Monitoring

Set up error logging and uptime monitoring. Check logs regularly at /var/log/ for any issues.

Important: Always test your deployment on a staging server before going live.
